PPCP specifically reduced metabolic activity (respiration rate and ethylene production), while MT improved membrane stability and reduced malondialdehyde content and electrolyte leakage.
population_specificity: "Keitt" mango fruit stored at 5 ± 1 °C.
effective_dosage: 20 μL L-1 PPCP or 200 μM MT.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the antifungal activity and underlying mechanism of putrescine against Colletotrichum gloeosporioides in harvested mango fruit.
results_summary: Putrescine delayed disease occurrence, limited spot expansion, enhanced disease resistance, and exhibited strong antifungal activity by inducing oxidative damage and leakage of cellular components in C. gloeosporioides.
population_specificity: Harvested mango fruit infected with C. gloeosporioides.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether reduced glutathione (GSH) treatment could improve the antioxidant capacity and postharvest quality of mango fruit.
results_summary: The 5 mM GSH treatment significantly reduced weight loss, soluble solids, and sugar content while increasing firmness, titratable acidity, and antioxidant enzyme activities, thereby maintaining mango quality during storage.
population_specificity: Mango fruit (Mangifera indica L.cv. Guixiang)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the feasibility of using mango tegument as a source of cellulosic pulp for manufacturing single-use articles or biopolymer blends.
results_summary: Alkali treatments yielded light-colored cellulosic pulp with 37-42% yield and reduced hemicellulose, while acid treatments produced orange-brown pulp with 47-48% yield and higher hemicellulose. Acid pulps showed higher thermal stability (348-357 °C) compared to alkali pulps (316-321 °C), making them suitable for disposable tableware and biopolymer blends.
population_specificity: Agro-industrial residues (mango tegument)
effective_dosage: Alkaline solutions (2% and 4% NaOH w/v), acetic acid solutions (1:1 or 1:2 CH3COOH:H2O2)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effectiveness of a chitosan-copper oxide nanocomposite film (CSC) in preserving mango fruit quality and extending shelf life by evaluating its morphological, mechanical, thermal, physical, and antifungal properties.
results_summary: The CSC coating significantly improved mango preservation by delaying decay and yellowing, reducing weight and firmness losses, decreasing respiration rate and ethylene generation, and maintaining high levels of ascorbic acid, titratable acid, and soluble sugar content. The coating also demonstrated good edible safety as copper was confined to the peel.
population_specificity: Mango fruit (Mangifera indica L.)
effective_dosage: Chitosan (2%, v/v) and copper oxide nanoparticles (500 μg∙mL-1)
study_duration: Duration of mango storage (specific length not mentioned in abstract)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of exogenous melatonin treatment on delaying postharvest deterioration and enhancing physiological and metabolic processes in two mango cultivars during cold storage.
results_summary: Melatonin treatment significantly delayed weight loss, firmness, respiration rate, and decay incidence in both mango cultivars. It also inhibited the decrease in total phenol, flavonoid, and AsA content while enhancing antioxidant enzyme activities and gene expression, though effects were cultivar-dependent.
population_specificity: Two mango cultivars (specific types not named in the abstract)
study_duration: Duration of cold storage (specific length not mentioned)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of calcium chloride (CaCl2) and chitosan coatings on preserving the quality, color, antioxidant content, and moisture of ripe mango pieces during frozen storage.
results_summary: Treatment with 1% CaCl2 for 30 minutes significantly delayed color changes, while 0.5% CaCl2 for 30 minutes preserved total phenolics, flavonoids, and antioxidant activities. Chitosan (0.5%-1% for 1 minute) effectively reduced moisture and weight loss.
population_specificity: Ripe mango pieces (no human subjects specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether 1-MCP alone or combined with melatonin (MT) improves the quality characteristics and antioxidant activities of postharvest mango fruit during storage.
results_summary: Mango fruit treated with 1-MCP alone or 1-MCP + MT showed better appearance, higher levels of soluble sugar, ascorbic acid, and titratable acidity, delayed color changes, reduced oxidative stress markers, and increased antioxidant enzyme activities compared to untreated fruit. The combination treatment (1-MCP + MT) was more effective than 1-MCP alone in enhancing quality and regulating active metabolism.
population_specificity: Mango fruit (Tainong No. 1)
effective_dosage: 0.1 mg/L 1-MCP alone or combined with 0.2 mM melatonin (MT)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the anti-adipogenic effects of mango leaf tea (MLT) and mangiferin (MGF) in cultured adipocytes to assess their potential for treating obesity.
results_summary: MLT and MGF increased glucose uptake in adipocytes, but only MLT inhibited adipogenesis by reducing triglyceride accumulation. MLT also increased adiponectin secretion and altered gene expression related to lipid metabolism, while MGF did not show these effects.
population_specificity: 3T3-L1 cultured adipocytes (in vitro study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of mango seed kernel biochar (both pristine and nano-ceria-laden) in removing antibiotics (rifampicin and tigecycline) from wastewater.
results_summary: The study found that nano-ceria-laden mango seed kernel biochar (Ce-Py-MSK) had higher adsorption efficiency for both antibiotics compared to pristine biochar (Py-MSK), achieving 92.36% removal for rifampicin and 90.13% for tigecycline. The adsorbent demonstrated high surface area and fit well with Freundlich isotherm and pseudo-second-order kinetic models.
population_specificity: Wastewater treatment (no human or animal subjects).
effective_dosage: Not specified (adsorbent dosage varied in experiments).
study_duration: Not specified (contact time varied in experiments).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of melatonin (MT) and tragacanth gum (TRG) as postharvest treatments to preserve mango quality during storage.
results_summary: All treatments (MT, TRG, and MT-TRG) significantly preserved mango quality compared to control, with MT-TRG showing the best results in reducing decay, respiration rates, ethylene production, and weight loss while maintaining appearance, flesh color, firmness, and biochemical markers.
population_specificity: Mango fruits (Mangifera indica L.) stored postharvest.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the antiproliferative and antioxidant effects of mango seed kernel extract (KE), peel extract (PE), and their combination (KEPE) on DMBA-induced mammary tumors in rats.
results_summary: The study found that KE, PE, and KEPE reduced oxidative stress, decreased cell proliferation, and increased apoptosis in DMBA-induced mammary tumors, demonstrating potential therapeutic effects. No adverse effects were reported after 4 weeks of administration.
population_specificity: Adult female Sprague-Dawley rats with DMBA-induced mammary tumors.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to understand the molecular mechanisms of salt tolerance in mango by comparing transcriptomic responses between salt-tolerant and salt-susceptible mango genotypes.
results_summary: The study identified differentially expressed genes related to salt tolerance, including transcription factors and genes involved in ABA biosynthesis and photosynthesis, with contrasting expression patterns between the tolerant (Turpentine) and susceptible (Mylepelian) genotypes.
population_specificity: Two polyembryonic mango genotypes (Turpentine and Mylepelian).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the role of MiFPF genes in mango (Mangifera indica L.) in promoting flowering and root growth under gibberellin treatment.
results_summary: The study found that MiFPF genes were expressed in all mango tissues, with specific genes highly expressed in leaves, flowers, and buds. Overexpression of MiFPFs in transgenic Arabidopsis led to early flowering, upregulated flowering-related genes, and increased root growth under gibberellin treatment.
population_specificity: Transgenic Arabidopsis plants (model organism for genetic studies).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the effects of fresh mango consumption on gut microbiome diversity, gut permeability proteins, and bowel movement habits in overweight/obese individuals.
results_summary: Mango consumption increased microbiome diversity and altered specific bacterial abundances compared to low-fat cookies, but did not significantly affect gut permeability proteins or most bowel movement metrics.
population_specificity: Overweight/obese individuals

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate an eco-friendly film infused with Melaleuca alternifolia essential oil as an alternative to chemical fungicides for controlling post-harvest fungal diseases in mango.
results_summary: The film with 1.2 wt% essential oil effectively inhibited fungal growth in vitro and reduced disease incidence in wounded mangoes. In unwounded mangoes, it reduced weight loss, increased soluble solid content, and improved firmness, though color index was unaffected.
population_specificity: Post-harvest mangoes (both wounded and unwounded).
effective_dosage: Film incorporated with 1.2 wt% essential oil.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how light treatment affects flavonoid biosynthesis, peel coloration, and fruit quality in postharvest mango.
results_summary: Light treatment enhanced red peel coloration, increased total soluble solids and flesh firmness, and upregulated flavonoid-related genes and transcription factors. It also promoted the accumulation of flavonols, proanthocyanidins, and anthocyanins.
population_specificity: Green-mature fruits of red mango cultivar 'Zill'

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify the pathogen causing stem-end rot in mango fruits during storage in China and confirm its pathogenicity.
results_summary: The study identified Botryosphaeria fabicerciana as the causative agent of stem-end rot in mango fruits, confirmed through morphological, molecular, and pathogenicity testing. The pathogen was re-isolated from symptomatic tissue, fulfilling Koch's postulates.
population_specificity: Mango fruits harvested from Baise Municipal National Agricultural Science and Technology Park in Guangxi province, China.
effective_dosage: Not applicable (pathogen study, no dosage tested).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate entomopathogenic fungi for controlling Anastrepha obliqua, a major pest of mango in Colombia.
results_summary: The study identified a Metarhizium robertsii strain with high insecticidal activity, causing up to 100% mortality in A. obliqua adults within 48 hours, primarily due to destruxin A. Two other compounds (destruxin A2 and B) showed moderate activity, with mortalities between 60.0% and 81.3%.
population_specificity: Anastrepha obliqua (mango pest insects)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if weeds could enhance beneficial insect abundance, diversity, and soil health in mango cultivation.
results_summary: Weeds significantly increased pollinating and parasitoid insect abundance and diversity, improved soil carbon and pH, but had no effect on predatory insects, soil nitrogen, phosphorous, or leaf chlorophyll in productive green leaves.
population_specificity: Mango cultivation in southern Florida.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of ultrasound-assisted extraction (UAE) on the yield and properties of starch isolated from mango kernels for potential industrial applications.
results_summary: Ultrasound-assisted extraction increased starch yield (up to 54%) and improved functional properties such as amylose content, water-holding capacity, and antioxidant activity. Rheological and pasting properties were also modified, suggesting potential for use in thermally processed foods.
population_specificity: Not applicable (in vitro study on mango kernel starch).
effective_dosage: Different power sonication conditions (120, 300, and 480 W) and sonication times (10, 20, and 30 min).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify the molecular mechanisms and key genes involved in light-regulated flavonoids biosynthesis in mango fruit peel.
results_summary: The study found that bagging treatment inhibited flavonols and anthocyanins but promoted proanthocyanidins accumulation in mango peel, identifying 16 crucial biosynthetic genes and key transcription factors (MYB, bHLH, ERF, WRKY, bZIP) involved in this regulation. Surprisingly, two HY5 transcripts, typically light-induced, showed higher expression in bagged samples.
population_specificity: Mango (Mangifera indica L.) cultivar 'Sensation' fruit peel.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the extraction, identification, quantification, and potential applications of bioactive compounds in mango by-products over the last ten years.
results_summary: Mango by-products, particularly peels and seeds, contain bioactive compounds like polyphenols and carotenoids with antioxidant and antimicrobial properties. These compounds show potential applications in food, active packaging, oil and fat, and pharmaceuticals, though most studies remain at the laboratory level.
population_specificity: Not specified (review of existing studies)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop a competitive lateral flow immunoassay (LFIA) using silver nanoparticles derived from mango leaves for detecting Staphylococcus aureus in cow milk.
results_summary: The assay detected Staphylococcus aureus at concentrations as low as 1000 cfu/ml with high accuracy (97.39%), specificity (98.03%), and sensitivity (96.1%). The method was validated using 230 raw and clinical mastitis milk samples and completed within 7-8 hours.
population_specificity: Cow milk samples (raw and clinical mastitis).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the composition and technofunctional properties of almond flours from 12 mango varieties to evaluate their potential use in breadmaking, focusing on dough rheology.
results_summary: Mango almond flours showed high starch content (60-65%), significant phenolic compounds (1-7%), lipids (7-13%), and proteins (4-7%), with local varieties having higher polyphenol and lipid levels. Composite flours with up to 10% wheat substitution were acceptable for breadmaking, with 9 varieties potentially reducing bread staling.
population_specificity: Mango varieties from savannah zones of Cameroon (Central Africa).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the entomopathogenic potential of Clonostachys rosea against mango hopper (Amritodus atkinsoni) and optimize its mass culturing conditions for pest management.
results_summary: The study found that C. rosea caused 96.67% mortality in A. atkinsoni at a concentration of 3 × 10⁸ conidia/mL after 168 hours. Oatmeal agar media and broth, along with a 20 °C temperature, were identified as optimal for mass culturing C. rosea.
population_specificity: Mango hopper (Amritodus atkinsoni) pests.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the metabolic changes during mango floral induction (FI) in response to SPD treatment and its impact on flowering rate and yield.
results_summary: SPD treatment significantly enhanced mango flowering and yield over two years, with notable metabolic changes, including upregulation of lipids, amino acids, and carbohydrates, particularly from 80 to 100 days post-treatment.
population_specificity: Mango plants (specific cultivar not mentioned)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate how postharvest application of phenylalanine enhances mango fruit's tolerance to suboptimal cold storage by analyzing transcriptomic and metabolomic changes.
results_summary: Phenylalanine-treated mango fruit showed reduced chilling injuries (black spot, pitting, electrolyte leakage) and decay during cold storage. The treatment upregulated genes related to defense pathways, increased flavonoid and antioxidant levels, and reduced oxidative damage markers like lipid peroxidation and volatile aldehydes.
population_specificity: Mango fruit (no human or animal subjects).
study_duration: Duration of suboptimal cold storage (specific length not stated).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to study the effect of hydrogel as a soil conditioner on the growth and yield of Shelly cv. mango trees.
results_summary: All hydrogel treatments improved vegetative growth, yield, and fruit quality compared to the control, with the 750 g hydrogel∙tree-1 treatment showing the highest values in these parameters. The improvements were dose-dependent.
population_specificity: Shelly cv. mango trees in arid and semi-arid conditions.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effect of Tragacanth gum (TCG) coating on delaying postharvest ripening and softening of mango fruits.
results_summary: Mango fruits coated with 1.5% TCG showed reduced disease incidence, weight loss, ethylene biosynthesis, and respiration rates, along with higher firmness and delayed ripening compared to untreated controls. The coating also maintained higher chlorophyll content and antioxidative enzyme activity while reducing cell wall degradation enzymes.
population_specificity: Harvested mango fruits (no human subjects).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of hydrocolloid edible coatings, particularly Xanthan gum, in preserving mango quality and extending shelf life during ambient storage.
results_summary: Xanthan gum (0.3%) treatment significantly reduced decay and physiological losses, maintained fruit quality, and extended shelf life by 6 days compared to control. It also lowered enzyme activities linked to fruit softening while preserving biochemical content.
population_specificity: Mango fruit stored under ambient conditions (25±4°C and 65±5% RH).
effective_dosage: Carboxymethyl cellulose (1%), Guar gum (1.5%), Gum Arabica (10%), Xanthan gum (0.3%) as dip treatments.
study_duration: Not explicitly stated, but shelf life extension was measured up to physiological loss standard (≤10%).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify prognostic biomarkers, specifically EGFR membrane expression, for anti-angiogenic therapy in ovarian cancer patients treated with bevacizumab.
results_summary: The study found that strong and homogeneous EGFR membrane localization was an independent negative prognostic factor for overall survival in ovarian cancer patients treated with anti-angiogenic therapy. Additionally, a functional cross-talk between EGFR and AXL RTK was identified, suggesting potential therapeutic targets.
population_specificity: 310 ovarian cancer patients from the MITO-16A/MANGO-OV2A trial.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the feasibility and performance of academic genomic tests and a functional assay (RAD51 foci) for detecting homologous recombination deficiency (HRD) in ovarian cancer patients, compared to the commercial MyChoice CDx test.
results_summary: The academic genomic tests showed low failure rates (2%) and high sensitivity (98.1% and 90.6%) and agreement (κ=0.84 and 0.74) with Myriad. The RAD51 foci assay had a higher failure rate (30%) and lower agreement (κ=0.18) but identified additional HRD patients. HRD status correlated with progression-free survival.
population_specificity: 100 patients with high-grade ovarian cancer enrolled in the MITO16A/MaNGO-OV2 trial.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the impact of mango consumption on metabolic pathways by analyzing gene expression changes and cardiometabolic outcomes in participants.
results_summary: The study identified two subgroups (responders and non-responders) based on gene expression profiles, with responders showing significant up-regulation of 280 transcripts and down-regulation of 603 transcripts, along with beneficial changes in hip and waist circumference, c-reactive protein, HOMA-IR, and QUICKI indices. Metabolic pathways related to oxygen/carbon dioxide transport and oxidative stress were enriched in responders.
population_specificity: 26 men and women

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of mango leaf extract (MLE) on schizophrenia-like symptoms in a maternal immune activation model, comparing its efficacy to risperidone.
results_summary: Adolescent MLE treatment prevented sensorimotor gating deficits, reduced grooming behavior, and partially counteracted brain structural changes, while adult MLE treatment reversed prepulse inhibition deficits but not other symptoms. MLE also reduced inflammatory markers and promoted antioxidant activity in key brain regions.
population_specificity: Male offspring of pregnant rats exposed to maternal immune activation, studied in adolescence (postnatal day 35-49) and young adulthood (postnatal day 60-70).
study_duration: Duration not explicitly stated (daily administration during adolescence or adulthood phases)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a combination of luteolin (from peanut husk extract) and mangiferin (from mango leaf extract) affects exercise capacity.
results_summary: The abstract mentions that mangiferin and luteolin have antioxidant properties but does not provide specific results on their effects on exercise capacity.
population_specificity: Not specified in the abstract.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of Swell-Drying (SD) on mango drying kinetics, including starting accessibility, apparent drying coefficient, and time to achieve a final moisture content of 20% d.b.
results_summary: SD significantly improved drying efficiency, increasing the apparent drying coefficient (Dapp) and starting accessibility (δW) by 12.2 and 2.7 times, respectively, compared to the control. It also reduced post-drying time from 30.8 hours to 2.4 hours.
population_specificity: Not specified (likely mango samples in a controlled lab setting).
effective_dosage: Steam pressure (0.2-0.6 MPa) and treatment time (5-55 s) during DIC treatment.
study_duration: Not explicitly stated (implied by drying stages).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of different vacuum impregnation methods (with or without osmotic treatment and ultrasound) on the quality of dried mango impregnated with grape residue flour polyphenols.
results_summary: Shorter drying times and lower oxygen exposure led to higher retention of carotenoids, phenolic compounds, and ascorbic acid. Ultrasound-assisted vacuum impregnation improved drying rates and carotenoid retention, while osmotic dehydration-assisted impregnation enhanced phenolic retention, and osmosonication-assisted impregnation preserved ascorbic acid. Sensory evaluation showed good acceptance of impregnated samples.
population_specificity: Not specified (likely general food consumers).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of an 8-week Bajiquan training intervention on physical fitness, body composition, and perceived exercise benefits.
results_summary: The experimental group showed significant improvements in social relationships, personal benefits, body composition (weight, BMI, body fat percentage), and physical fitness (explosive power, cardiorespiratory fitness, core muscle strength) compared to the control group.
population_specificity: Adults (mean age ~26-27 years, 13.3% female).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the immediate effects of game-ready contrast therapy (GRT) and contrast water immersion therapy (CWT) on stiffness, muscle tone, flexibility, pressure pain threshold, and isometric muscle strength in MMA trainees.
results_summary: Both GRT and CWT significantly reduced muscle tone, stiffness, and elasticity while increasing pressure pain threshold and isometric strength, with effects lasting up to 1 hour post-therapy. GRT showed a larger effect on muscle tone reduction compared to CWT, but other outcomes were similar between the two therapies.
population_specificity: Thirty MMA trainees (age: 28.20 ± 7.57 years, BMI: 26.35 ± 4.06, training experience: 10.37 ± 7.34 years).
study_duration: Single session per therapy, with a 2-week break between GRT and CWT phases.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to analyze craniofacial injuries in mixed martial arts (MMA) to identify gaps in diagnosis, treatment, and prevention strategies.
results_summary: The study found 54,787 cases of craniofacial injuries in MMA over 10 years, with the highest incidence in males aged 20-29. Most injuries affected the head, and internal injuries were the most common diagnosis, though the majority did not require hospitalization.
population_specificity: MMA athletes, predominantly males aged 15-29.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to quantitatively assess the impact of plyometric training on muscle strength and power in martial arts athletes and investigate potential moderators of this relationship.
results_summary: Plyometric training had a small-to-moderate positive effect on muscle strength and power in martial arts athletes, with no significant influence from age or training parameters.
population_specificity: Martial arts athletes aged 12 to 24 years (total 499 participants).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of martial arts on BDNF and irisin levels, cognitive function, mood, and physical measures in older adults.
results_summary: Martial arts significantly increased BDNF levels and showed cognitive and mood improvements, though irisin levels did not change significantly. Anthropometric changes were linked to irisin levels.
population_specificity: Independently living older adults (mean age 70.3±3.8 years).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of dry needling (DN) on muscle tone, stiffness, elasticity, power, pressure pain thresholds, and blood perfusion in MMA athletes.
results_summary: A single session of DN significantly improved muscle recovery, strength, and pressure pain thresholds, with effects lasting up to 48 hours in some variables.
population_specificity: 32 trained/developmental male MMA fighters (25.5±4.5 years; BMI 24.5±3).
study_duration: Outcomes assessed at baseline, immediately after, and 24 and 48 hours post-intervention.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of traditional Chinese martial arts (TCMA) and stretching training (ST) on symptoms of fibromyalgia syndrome (FMS), including pain, fatigue, and sleep quality.
results_summary: TCMA and ST interventions significantly improved FIQ scores, pain symptoms, fatigue levels, and sleep quality in FMS patients compared to control groups, with TCMA particularly benefiting sleep quality and ST improving fatigue symptoms.
population_specificity: Patients with fibromyalgia syndrome (FMS).
study_duration: Not specified (subgroup analyses noted effectiveness irrespective of duration)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the evidence from RCTs on the effectiveness of Irvingia gabonensis (African Bush Mango) for body weight reduction in obese and overweight individuals.
results_summary: The RCTs reported statistically significant reductions in body weight and waist circumference favoring I. gabonensis over placebo, with positive effects on blood lipid profile. However, due to poor reporting quality and methodological flaws, the effects remain unproven, and the supplement cannot be recommended as a weight loss aid.
population_specificity: Obese and overweight individuals (no age or gender restrictions).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the potential benefits of martial arts training on attention and executive function, particularly in the context of cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT).
results_summary: The study found that martial arts training shows promise in enhancing attention and executive function, suggesting it could be a beneficial supplementary strategy in CBT for cognitive improvement.
population_specificity: Individuals with cognitive impairments, such as those with depression or attention deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of different durations of cold and heat compression using the Game Ready (GR) device on biomechanical changes in the forearm muscles of MMA athletes.
results_summary: Both 10-minute and 20-minute GR stimulations significantly improved muscle tone, stiffness, flexibility, pain threshold, microvascular response, and maximum isometric strength, with the 20-minute duration showing superior improvements in some outcomes. The study suggests that 10-minute GR stimulation is sufficient for optimizing recovery in MMA athletes.
population_specificity: 20 healthy mixed martial arts athletes (26.5±4.5 years old).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effectiveness of cryo-compression therapy (3 and 6 minutes) on forearm muscles in MMA fighters by evaluating muscle pain, stiffness, tension, elasticity, strength, and perfusion.
results_summary: Cryo-compression therapy significantly affected muscle biomechanical properties, pain threshold, strength, and tissue perfusion, with notable differences between 3- and 6-minute sessions for perfusion and muscle tone, and significant pre-to-post changes in force, elasticity, pain threshold, and stiffness.
population_specificity: Twenty professional male MMA fighters aged 26.5 ± 4.5 years with 10.3 ± 5.0 years of training experience.
effective_dosage: 3 °C at 75 mmHg for 3 minutes and 6 minutes in separate sessions.
study_duration: Two sessions (3 min and 6 min each).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the immediate effects of dry needling (DN) therapy on biomechanical properties, muscle power, perfusion, and pressure pain threshold in the gastrocnemius muscle of MMA athletes with latent trigger points.
results_summary: DN significantly increased muscle perfusion, reduced tone and stiffness, improved elasticity, increased pressure pain threshold, and enhanced muscle power, with effects maintained at 24 hours. The therapy also had an analgesic effect, suggesting potential for post-exercise muscle recovery in MMA athletes.
population_specificity: Twenty mixed martial arts (MMA) athletes with latent trigger points in the gastrocnemius muscle.
effective_dosage: One session of dry needling (real or sham).
study_duration: Immediate effects measured at 1-5 minutes and 24 hours post-intervention.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether combined probiotic and vitamin D3 supplementation could modify gut microbiome composition, improve epithelial cell permeability, reduce inflammation, and enhance aerobic capacity in MMA athletes.
results_summary: The study found that combined probiotic and vitamin D3 supplementation significantly reduced calprotectin levels, increased beta diversity of the gut microbiome, and extended time to exhaustion during exercise in MMA athletes. No significant effects were observed in the vitamin D3-only group.
population_specificity: 23 male MMA athletes

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the validity of the King-Devick (KD) test and SCAT5 in detecting traumatic and perfusion events in MMA fighters and assess whether these events cause similar changes in test scores.
results_summary: The KD test showed high specificity (93.39%) but low sensitivity (21.05%) for traumatic events, while SCAT5 demonstrated reasonable sensitivity (77.78%) but lower specificity (52.99%). Traumatic events caused significant changes in KD and SCAT5 scores, but perfusion events did not.
population_specificity: 140 MMA athletes (7 women, 133 men), mean age 27.1 ± 4.9 years.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to report the incidence and characteristics of injuries from various martial arts disciplines presenting to US emergency rooms to educate participants and providers about associated risks.
results_summary: The study found 310,143 martial arts-related injuries over 11 years, with strains/sprains, fractures, and contusions/abrasions being most common. Lower extremity injuries were more frequent, and only 2.2% of patients required hospital admission.
population_specificity: Patients presenting to US emergency rooms with martial arts-related injuries (2009-2019).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether martial arts training could serve as exercise therapy to enhance overall health across all age groups.
results_summary: The study found that martial arts training positively impacts physical, psychological, and cognitive well-being in older adults and children, including those with clinical conditions. The researchers hypothesize its potential as a broad therapeutic intervention.
population_specificity: Older adults and children, with and without clinical conditions.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the types and prevalence of musculoskeletal injuries in martial arts practitioners and discuss orthopaedic management strategies.
results_summary: The study found that martial arts predispose practitioners to various musculoskeletal injuries, with anterior cruciate ligament ruptures being the most common. Approximately 60% of martial artists return to preinjury participation levels after major injuries, and injury prevention programs should focus on neuromotor control and core engagement.
population_specificity: Martial arts practitioners, including full-contact and noncontact athletes, as well as pediatric participants.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a 4-week martial-arts-based meditative intervention could reduce cancer-related posttraumatic stress symptoms (PTSS) in pediatric patients and survivors, and whether baseline hippocampal volumes correlated with PTSS severity or intervention response.
results_summary: The intervention did not significantly reduce PTSS overall. However, smaller hippocampal volume was associated with more severe re-experiencing PTSS at baseline and greater reductions in PTSS post-intervention, suggesting hippocampal volume may serve as a biomarker for PTSS severity and intervention response.
population_specificity: Pediatric patients and survivors of cancer.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of vitamin D3 alone versus probiotics combined with vitamin D3 on sports performance markers in MMA athletes.
results_summary: Combined probiotic and vitamin D3 supplementation improved lactate utilization, total work, and mean power during anaerobic exercise in MMA athletes, while vitamin D3 alone showed no significant improvements in these metrics.
population_specificity: 23 male MMA athletes

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of an educational pamphlet versus a mobile application in improving knowledge and self-reported preventive practices for sport-related traumatic dental injuries (TDIs) among adolescent Karate and Taekwondo athletes.
results_summary: Both the pamphlet and mobile application significantly improved knowledge and self-reported preventive practices regarding TDI prevention after three months, with no statistically significant difference between the two methods. Most athletes were satisfied with both interventions.
population_specificity: 11-17-year-old Karate and Taekwondo athletes.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how martial arts, compared to free-play and rest, improves neurocognitive functions and brain activity in school-aged children.
results_summary: Martial arts significantly improved attention and working memory compared to free-play and rest, with higher activation in specific brain regions (right orbitofrontal cortex and right Broca's area) and better performance in cognitive tasks. However, under higher cognitive load (2-back task), martial arts reduced activation in some brain areas despite improved cognitive control.
population_specificity: School-aged children

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether judo training could improve response inhibition in children born very preterm and children with ADHD.
results_summary: Judo training reduced commission errors and increased P3a amplitude in children born very preterm but showed no significant effects in children with ADHD. No improvements were observed in N2, P3b, or physical fitness outcomes.
population_specificity: Children born very preterm (CHIPMANC study) and children with ADHD (JETPAC study).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to study the effect of ankle proprioceptive training on preventing ankle injuries in martial arts athletes and improving their dynamic and static balance.
results_summary: The study found that ankle proprioceptive training improved the dynamic and static balance of martial arts athletes and effectively prevented ankle injuries, with the experimental group showing a more significant reduction in stability index compared to the control group.
population_specificity: 16 martial arts athletes (8 males and 8 females)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to analyze the comprehensive intervention effect of martial arts routines on children with autism to provide references for treatment.
results_summary: The study found that martial arts routines improved language, perception, and social skills in children with autism, with language and behavior increasing by 19.1%, perception ability by 20.7%, and social ability by 5.9%. The results demonstrated that martial arts routines have a good effect in the intervention and treatment of autism.
population_specificity: Children with autism

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the safety and feasibility of returning to martial arts after cervical spine surgery.
results_summary: About 88% of martial arts practitioners returned to play after cervical spine surgery with no major complications reported; return times varied, with most returning within 6 months. The study noted low evidence levels due to reliance on case reports and heterogeneous data.
population_specificity: Athletes practicing martial arts (wrestling, kickboxing, sumo, judo, and unspecified martial arts) who underwent cervical spine surgery.
study_duration: Follow-up periods varied, with some returning within 0-3 months and others after more than 6 months.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the influence of Wushu (specifically Wuqinxi Wushu) on improving abnormal spinal morphological structures in adolescents and children.
results_summary: The study found that Wuqinxi Wushu improved abnormal spinal angles (dry tilt, kyphosis, and body balance) and enhanced spine activity in teenagers. The optimized ant colony algorithm also improved CT image segmentation efficiency and accuracy for spinal analysis.
population_specificity: Adolescents and children with abnormal spinal morphological development.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the effects of Chinese martial arts on the motor skills of preschool children aged 5−6 years, comparing sensory teaching (MAST) and traditional teaching (MATT) methods against free activity (FA).
results_summary: The study found that both MAST and MATT significantly improved balance compared to FA, with MAST showing superior results. MAST also significantly enhanced manual dexterity and overall motor skills compared to both MATT and FA.
population_specificity: Preschool children aged 5−6 years.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of martial arts programs on the physical fitness of preschool and school children, including motor skills and aerobic/anaerobic abilities.
results_summary: Martial arts programs (karate, judo, taekwondo, aikido) showed statistically significant improvements in physical fitness parameters such as cardiorespiratory fitness, speed, agility, strength, flexibility, coordination, and balance in children.
population_specificity: Preschool and school children (total participants: 1615, experimental group: 914, control group: 701).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the impact of a martial arts-based curriculum (Heroes Circle) on stress, emotional, and behavioral problems in elementary school children.
results_summary: Children reported increased mindfulness, decreased stress, and lower internalizing symptoms and COVID-19-related fears, with 77% still using the program's techniques and reporting benefits five months later. These positive outcomes were not observed in the control school.
population_specificity: Elementary school children
study_duration: Surveys were collected two and five months after COVID-19-related school shutdowns (exact intervention duration not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether extended martial arts training could improve cognitive and psychological functions in at-risk youths.
results_summary: Martial arts training significantly improved inhibition, shifting, and speed of processing. Hormonal reactivity (oxytocin and cortisol) predicted improvements in processing speed, aggression reduction, and self-esteem.
population_specificity: Adolescent boys attending specialized education facilities for at-risk youths.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the effects of resistive inspiratory muscle training (IMT) on pulmonary function variables in mixed martial arts (MMA) and kickboxing athletes.
results_summary: The study found that adding IMT to standard training significantly improved forced expiratory volume in the first second to vital capacity ratio (FEV1/VC) and maximum voluntary ventilation (MVV) in MMA athletes, but not in kickboxing athletes. The interaction between sport discipline and IMT intervention showed strong significant changes in MVV and FEV1/VC favoring MMA athletes.
population_specificity: Male athletes (14 kickboxers and 12 MMA fighters).
